subject: RE: [junit] Dogmatic or Heuristic?
msgSnippet: ... I hear you, but I still have a fundamental dislike for any kind of absolutes (and in particular, statements that contain always or never ). Instead of
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of J. B. Rainsberger

> The second question is perhaps more of a comment than a
> question. I think that when a novice asks us a question, it's
> OK for us to provide a simple, dogmatic-sounding answer. This
> person is learning, and is therefore not well-informed about
> the consequences of the choices he has in front of him. As a
> result, we have a responsibility to suggest the course we
> think is right and ask him to try it so he can learn the way
> we did. In this case, a little dogma doesn't hurt.

I hear you, but I still have a fundamental dislike for any kind of absolutes
(and in particular, statements that contain "always" or "never").

Instead of saying "Never do X", I much prefer to phrase my response in terms
of "If you do X, here is what you gain, and here are the risks".

I have been in this business for long enough that I can confidentially say
that whatever absolute statement you make, I'll be able to come up with a
counter example :-)
